body:
This behaviour has been the same since the command was first introduced to the Helm codebase, as can be viewed here:

https://github.com/helm/helm/commit/459338264e67bd2794580dd0b51cc556c8c35890

Helm 2.0.0 for reference:

https://github.com/helm/helm/blob/51bdad42756dfaf3234f53ef3d3cb6bcd94144c2/cmd/helm/repo_update.go#L88-L93

So yes I do believe it was intended behaviour that failing to fetch an index file does not cause `helm repo update` to error out.

I believe this is to consider cases where a user adds a repository to their repository list that is not part of the current chart's dependency tree. However this behaviour was introduced a long time ago so I may be missing some other key feature. But to answer your question @hickeyma


> I am unsure if this is as expected or not

Yes, it does appear to be intentional.

Because of that, I have a feeling that changing the behaviour would constitute a breaking change. The current behaviour does appear to be intentional, and has retained this behaviour since it was introduced back in 2016.

In my case, the update isn’t working at all because of the broken credentials, so it seems incorrect to return a success code.

Best, Rob
--
Rob Anderson
***@***.***

However this behaviour was introduced a long time ago so I may be missing some other key feature. But to answer your question @hickeyma <https://github.com/hickeyma>

> 
> Yes, it does appear to be intentional.
> 
> Because of that, I have a feeling that changing the behaviour would constitute a breaking change. The current behaviour does appear to be intentional, and has retained this behaviour since it was introduced back in 2016.
>

As discussed in the call, the best place to move this proposal forward would be to write a HIP.

For example, we need to re-define what we mean by "failure" - what if you have 18 repositories in your list and call help repo update. 17 succeed and one doesn't. Is that a successful update or not? Up until now that was considered a success with the caveat that a warning message was displayed on standard error. However if all 18 fail, we can all agree that the "repo update" failed.

The core maintainers did agree in the call that we should not surprise people by changing 5-year-old behaviour. So any changes to this behaviour would have to be introduced in Helm 4.

Please refer to CONTRIBUTING.md on how to move forward with the HIP process. Let us know if that's something you'd like to provide.

https://github.com/helm/helm/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md#proposing-an-idea.

If all you want to fix is the "if all repositories fail to update" case, we'd welcome a PR to do so in Helm 3. That might solve your current case (one repository), but it won't fix the case if you intend to add more than one repository to your list.

@knurl As @bacongobbler mentioned, this issue was discussed at the weekly call yesterday.

Just clarifying a few things:

- The behaviour cannot be changed in Helm 3 as it would break backward compatibility (rightly or wrongly users expect it to work in a certain way). It needs to be queued for Helm 4. 
- The issue can be viewed as a bug or working as expected depending on the standpoint. We did agree that the behaviour needs to be re-examined especially in light of how Helm has evolved, and the [deprecation of the Helm chart repository](https://helm.sh/blog/helm-2-becomes-unsupported/) which now means a lot more repositories being accessed.  The suggestion at the meeting was about [Proposing an Idea](https://github.com/helm/helm/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md#proposing-an-idea) around handling repositories and including how other package managers like `apt` work.
- @mattfarina showed interest in drafting a [HIP](https://github.com/helm/community/blob/main/hips/hip-0001.md) and @scottrigby also mentioned about being involved

I am going to set this as a proposal and target it for Helm 4. Once the HIP is drafted, you can add your feedback there.

Hope this helps.

That’s fair, I agree that we don’t want to break expected behaviour. We could pass a command line switch to augment the behaviour (possibly waiting for Helm 4), so that we would get a success code only if the update of all repos were successful. If the switch isn’t passed, then there is no change to existing behaviour, and any failures are not transmitted to the return code.

I’m not a huge fan of the idea of adding new command line options to affect return codes, but there is form there in tools like Terraform. However, right now I’m having to parse the output of the helm command to see if it failed, which also strikes me as really ugly, and is definitely extremely brittle and likely to break in the future.

Best, Rob
--
Rob Anderson
***@***.***
